verses: In the language of India: Bodhipathapradīpa. In Tibetan: byang chub lam gyi sgron ma [Lamp of the Path to Enlightenment].
I bow down to the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī Kumārabhūta.

To all the Conquerors of the three times, their dharma,
And the saṅgha, I pay homage with great devotion.
At the urging of my good disciple Changchub-O,
I will shine a lamp of the path to enlightenment.

Lesser, intermediate and supreme:
Thus the Three Persons are to be known.
I shall write to clarify the distinctions
Between each of their natures.

Someone using methods by which
They pursue, for their own good,
Mere saṃsāric happiness,
Should be known as inferior.

Someone who turns away from conditioned happiness
And desists from nonvirtuous actions,
Seeking only their own individual peace,
Should be called an intermediate person.

Someone who, by their own suffering,
Truly wishes to completely end
All the sufferings of others
Is a superior person.

For those excellent beings
Who want supreme enlightenment,
I will now explain the authentic means
Which has been taught by the lamas.

Before an image of the perfect Buddha,
A stupa, and the holy dharma,
Make offerings with whatever you have—
Flowers, incense, materials etc.

With the seven point offering taught in
Samanthabhadra’s Prayer for Good Conduct,
Until one’s destination, the heart of enlightenment, is reached,
With the pure intention never to stop,

Have strong faith in the Three Jewels
And, placing one knee on the ground,
With one’s palms together,
Begin by going for refuge three times.

Then, a loving intention towards
All sentient beings is the preliminary
To looking upon all beings, without exception,
Suffering throughout the three lower realms,
Birth, death, transmigration etc.

And wishing to set them free
From the sufferings that torment them,
From suffering, suffering, and its cause.
One should generate bodhicitta,
Which is an irreversible commitment.

That is the pure mind of aspiration.
The qualities of developing it
Have been well explained by Maitreya
In the Gaṇḍavyūha Sūtra.

One should read the sūtras or hear them from the lama,
For truly to understand the limitless qualities of the mind of perfect enlightenment
Will cause its stabilisation.
Again and again develop the intention in this way.

In the Sūtra of Vīradatta’s Questions
Its merit is explained fully.
There, in just three of its verses,
It is summarised, which I will now quote.

“What merit there is in bodhicitta,
If it could have form,
Would fill the realms of space,
And overflow even from this.”

“However many grains of sand there may be in
The Ganges, as many Buddha fields
Could be completely filled with gems
And offered by someone to the lords of the world,”

“But, if someone folds their hands
With devotion for enlightenment,
Their veneration is superior,
For there is no limit to that.”

Having developed true aspiration bodhicitta,
One should always increase it with all kinds of exertion.
In order to remember this as well in other lives,
Maintain assiduously the trainings just as they are explained.

Unless one holds the vow of application bodhicitta,
Aspiration will not develop to perfection.
Those wishing to increase the vow of perfect enlightenment
Should definitely make effort to take this vow.

Apart from always holding
The seven kinds of prātimokṣa,
The good fortune of this bodhisattva vow
Is not to be found anywhere.

Among the seven kinds of prātimokṣa
Explained by the Tathāgata,
The glorious Brahmā conduct is supreme.
The vows of the bhikṣu are to be known thus.

One should know the excellent lama
To be learned in the ritual of the vow,
To be someone who keeps the vow,
And to consent to bestow the vow with compassion.

Using the ritual taught in the chapter
On moral discipline in the Bodhisattvabhūmi,
Take the vow from the excellent lama
Who possesses the requisite characteristics.

For one who has tried but been unable
To find such a qualified lama,
I shall properly explain another ritual
To take the vow.

In a past age, Mañjuśrī,
When he was Ambarāja,
Generated bodhicitta in the way
That is taught in the sūtra of
The Ornament of Mañjuśrī’s Buddha Realm,
As I shall now relate here in full.

“In the presence of the Protectors,
I generate perfect bodhicitta.
Inviting all beings as my guests,
I will liberate them from saṃsāra.”

“From now until I have attained
Perfect enlightenment, I will cease
Intentions of harm, aggression,
Greed and envy.”

“I will practise pure conduct
And abandon nonvirtue and desire.
Taking joy in the vow of conduct,
I will train following the Buddhas.”

“Taking no pleasure in swiftly
Attaining enlightenment for myself,
I will remain until the end
For even a single being.”

“I will utterly purify
Inconceivable fields without limit.
For those who remember my name,
I will remain for them throughout the ten directions.”

“I will purify entirely
Actions of body and speech.
I will purify the activity of mind too,
And I will cease nonvirtuous actions.”

If one keeps the vow of application bodhicitta,
It is the cause of complete purification of body, speech, and mind.
If the moral conduct of the three trainings is properly practised,
Devotion to the moral conduct of the three trainings will grow greater.

Therefore, intent upon pure and perfect enlightenment,
Bodhisattvas will keep the vow of vows pure.
They will endeavour in perfect enlightenment
And completely fulfill the accumulations.

The cause of completely perfecting the accumulations,
The natures of which are merit and wisdom,
Is held by all the Buddhas
To be the development of the higher knowledges.

Just as a bird with unfledged wings
Cannot fly in the sky,
So, without the power of the higher knowledges,
One cannot benefit beings.

Whatever merit may be obtained in a single day
By someone endowed with the higher knowledges,
Will not be obtained in a hundred lifetimes
By someone who lacks them.

Those who want to complete swiftly
The accumulations of perfect enlightenment
Will accomplish the higher knowledges
Not through laziness but through effort.

Since without achieving calm abiding
The higher knowledges will not arise,
One should apply oneself again and again
In trying to accomplish calm abiding.

While the conditions of calm abiding are weak,
Even to meditate with strong diligence
For thousands of years
Will not accomplish samādhi.

Therefore, maintain well the conditions
Taught in the Tract on the Accumulation of Samādhi.
Place the mind in virtue
On any suitable object of attention.

When the yogin attains calm abiding,
The higher knowledges are attained also.
Yet without the yoga of the perfection of wisdom,
The obscurations will not be exhausted.

Therefore, in order to abandon completely
The obscurations of defilements and cognition,
Cultivate the perfection of wisdom
Always in conjunction with skilful means.

Wisdom without skilful means
And skilful means without wisdom
Were said to be prisons.
Do not therefore abandon either of them.

To eliminate doubts concerning
What ‘wisdom’ and ‘skilful means’ are,
I will now clarify the correct distinction
Between skilful means and wisdom.

Apart from the perfection of wisdom,
All virtuous dharmas,
Such as the perfection of giving,
Were taught by the Conquerors to be skilful means.

Whoever cultivates wisdom
Through the power of cultivating skilful means
Will soon attain enlightenment
But, by cultivating non-self alone, will not.

The skandhas, dhātus, and āyatanās
Are to be understood as being without arising.
This recognition of the emptiness of intrinsic nature
Is the definition of ‘wisdom’.

Arising from existence is not logical,
Nor is arising from nonexistence, like a skyflower.
Consequently both are errors.
Therefore there is no arising from both, either.

Objects do not arise from self,
Nor from other, nor from both,
Nor without cause, because of which,
They have no intrinsic nature.

Or, if all dharmas
Are analysed for singularity and multiplicity,
Since no essence is seen,
It is certain they have no intrinsic nature.

The arguments of the Seventy Verses on Emptiness,
The Root Verses on the Middle Way and so forth,
Show the proofs for the emptiness
Of the intrinsic nature of things.

Because this text would become too long,
I will not elaborate on them here,
But I have fully explained just the established tenets
For the purpose of meditation.

Therefore, whoever meditates upon non-self
Without seeing an intrinsic nature
Of any dharma whatsoever
Is meditating upon wisdom.

Just as one with wisdom does not see
Any intrinsic nature in all dharmas,
So wisdom itself is subject to analysis.
One should meditate without any concepts.

This world comes from conceptual discrimination.
Its very core is conceptual discrimination.
Therefore, abandon such discrimination entirely.
That is the supreme nirvāṇa.

Thus the Bhagavān said,
‘Conceptual discrimination is the great ignorance.
It plunges one into the ocean of saṃsāra.
Resting in non-discriminating samādhi,
Sky-like non-discrimination will be revealed.’

In the Dhāraṇī of Entering into Non-discrimination Sūtra it likewise says,
‘Should sons of the Conquerors meditate upon
This sacred teaching of non-discrimination,
They will escape the struggles of discrimination,
And gradually achieve non-discrimination.’

With scriptures and reasoning,
Having made certain that all dharmas
Are nonarising, without intrinsic nature,
Meditate without discrimination.

Thus if one meditates upon suchness
And attains the successive stages of heat etc.,
Then one will attain the Joyful bhūmi and the rest,
And the enlightenment of a Buddha will not be far off.

With activities such as pacifying and increasing,
And also with powers such as the eight great attainments,
Like the excellent vase attainment,
Which are accomplished through the power of mantra,

If one wishes to fulfil completely with ease
The accumulations of enlightenment,
And if one wishes for the conduct of the secret mantras
Taught in Kriyā, Caryā etc. tantras,

Then, for the ācārya empowerment,
One should please the holy lama with all one has,
Such as with veneration and with gifts, such as jewels,
And by accomplishing his instructions.

The one who pleases the lama
Will perfectly receive the ācārya empowerment.
All of one’s nonvirtues will be utterly purified
And one will become worthy of accomplishing siddhis.

Because the great Paramādibuddha tantra
Expressly forbids it,
Those observing pure conduct
Should not receive the secret and wisdom empowerments.

Should these empowerments be received
By those keeping the discipline of pure conduct,
Because its conduct has been forbidden,
Their vows of discipline would be broken.

This would be a defeat
Of the discipline they were holding and a downfall,
And since they would be sure to fall into the lower realms,
They could not attain siddhis.

Hearing and explaining all the tantras,
Performing fire pūjās, offerings, and so forth,
Are not faults for those who have received
The ācārya empowerment and know thusness.

Upon the supplication of Changchub-O,
I, the Sthavira Dīpaṃkaraśrī,
Have given this brief explanation of the path to enlightenment,
As I have seen it explained in teachings such as the sūtras.
The Lamp of the Path to Enlightenment, composed by the great ācārya Dīpaṃkara Śrījñāna is completed.
It was translated and checked by the great master of India himself and the great translator and editor, Gewa'i Lodro.
